content: The amount of time it takes for the body to adapt to a higher elevation will vary depending on several factors, including the individual's fitness level, age, and altitude level. In general, however, it can take several days to a few weeks for the body to fully acclimate to moderate altitudes, such as 6,000 to 8,000 feet (1,828 to 2,438 meters). Once acclimatization has occurred, an individual's body will be able to more efficiently transport oxygen and remove carbon dioxide, helping to increase endurance performance. If you plan on acclimatizing before a race, it's recommended that you spend at least 2-3 days at a moderate elevation before heading to a higher elevation. This will allow enough time for your body to begin adapting to the lower oxygen levels. However, if you are unable to spend several days at a moderate elevation before heading to a higher elevation, you can still benefit from acclimatization techniques such as using an altitude tent or training mask to expose your body to simulated high altitude environments.
